newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill spot end mixed, repo rates up.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill spot end mixed, repo rates up.

text.p: Contracts on the Treasury bill spot market in Shanghai ended mixed on Tuesday, with a surge in the new three-year bond that matures in August 1999 thanks to an interest rate cut by the central bank last week, traders said.

The three-year bond, making its debut today, closed at 105.86 yuan, up 5.86 percent from an issue price of 100.00 yuan. It opened at 106.80 yuan and hit a high of 107.00 yuan in early trading. Volume was very heavy at 9.93 million lots.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
Combined volume of the eight-contract market rose to 12.1 million lots from 3.02 million on Monday.
The ten-year bond that matures in June 2006, regarded as a market barometer, ended slightly up at 124.00 yuan from 123.99.
Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai ended mostly up on Tuesday, with turnover falling slightly to 9.78 million lots from 9.79 million.
The annual rate for the three-day contract closed up at 13.00 percent from 9.85 percent on Monday and the most active seven-day contract ended up at 10.10 percent from 9.15.
Traders said the uptrend was mainly due to today's rise in the domestic A share market, which atttracted funds from the repo market. -- Shanghai newsroom (86-21) 6279-7004
